p.s: Emended description of the genus Prosthecochloris
The genus Prosthecochloris comprises green sulfur bacteria with spherical to ovoid, vibrioid or rod-shaped cells that develop as single cells and may form non-branching prosthecae.
Some species and strains may contain gas vesicles.
The cell size ranges from 0·5 to 0·8 μm in width.
As photosynthetic pigments, either BChl c and d or BChl e is present.
The former are accompanied by carotenoids of the chlorobactene series, the latter by those of the isorenieratene series.
Vitamin B12 is a growth factor.
The genus comprises those strains and species that belong phylogenetically to group 1 of the green sulfur bacteria, according to Alexander et al. (2002).
Photolithoautotrophic growth occurs under anoxic conditions in the light, with reduced sulfur compounds such as sulfide and elemental sulfur as electron donors.
During oxidation of sulfide, elemental sulfur is transiently deposited outside cells.
In the presence of sulfide and bicarbonate, simple organic substrates are photoassimilated.
The DNA G+C content is 52·0–56·1 mol% (Bd).
The type species is Prosthecochloris aestuarii Gorlenko 1970, 148.
